etymologies: Middle English gilofre (in the sense ‘clove’), from Old French gilofre, girofle, via medieval Latin from Greek karuophullon (from karuon ‘nut’ + phullon ‘leaf’). The ending was altered by association with flower, but gilliver survived in dialect

definitions: any of a number of fragrant flowers, such as the wallflower, clove pink, or white stock.
shortDefinitions: several fragrant flowers, such as wallflower or white stock
